title: Sarangbang
text: Sarangbang (사랑방, 舍廊房) is a room located in a Korean traditional <a href="house">house</a> (<a href="hanok">hanok</a>) which served as a man's room, used for studying, writing poetry, and leisure activities. The Koreans created the sarangbang strictly following the <a href="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> principles of the <a href="Joseon%20Dynasty">Joseon Dynasty</a>. In lower-class homes, the sarangbang is located across from the women's space (<a href="Anbang%20%28room%29">anbang</a>), separated with a hall called a <a href="daecheong">daecheong</a>. One of the characteristics of the sarangbang is that it usually has a separate <a href="study%20%28room%29">study</a> called a sarangchae. The sarangchae is forbidden to women and only men can enter it.
